TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was married to PERSON who was a member of PERSON ( bytové družstvo ) which assigned a flat to him . At that time the applicant was not a member of the cooperative . The couple lived in the flat under a lease and , by operation of law , they had the right of joint use ( právo spoločného užívania ) .
In DATE the marriage was dissolved and PERSON moved out of the flat .

In DATE ORG ( then ORG súd , at present PERSON súd ) cancelled the applicant ’s and her former husband ’s right of joint use of the flat and ruled that the sole legal tenant was PERSON The applicant was ordered to move out within DATE of the date when a substitute dwelling was provided to her . Until then , the applicant would have an absolute right to stay in the flat ( právo bývania ) .
As no substitute dwelling has ever been provided to her , the applicant continues to enjoy her right to stay in the flat .
In DATE the applicant became a so called “ non - resident member ” of the cooperative . In DATE she transferred the membership to a third person . In DATE she again became a non - resident member .

In DATE the cooperative ’s board passed a decision excluding Mr B. from its membership for breach of duties . It was noted that he had not been using the flat since DATE . PERSON appealed against this decision , but his appeal has never been formally determined .

On DATE the board annulled its decision of DATE . The validity of the annulment is disputed . It was investigated following the applicant ’s criminal complaint , but no charges were ever brought . The matter was considered to be of a private - law nature and , as such , fell to be determined by the ordinary courts . No criminal case to answer was detected .

In DATE PERSON petitioned for the applicant ’s eviction on the basis of the DATE judgment . On DATE the Bratislava III ORG ( then ORG , at present ORG súd ) dismissed the petition holding that PERSON rights under that judgment were statute - barred .

In DATE the applicant invited the cooperative to sell her the flat under special legislation - Flats and NORP - residential LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended - “ the DATE LAW ) - which provided for the transfer of ownership of flats to tenants for a regulated price . She did not receive an answer .
In DATE the cooperative sold the flat to PERSON under LAW .

The sale was registered in ORG and PERSON became the legal owner of the flat . The applicant subsequently challenged the validity of the sale in the ordinary courts . The course and outcome of her action is a separate subject - matter of the present application and is described in detail below .

On DATE , following numerous arguments and disturbances , PERSON and his lawyer , PERSON , arranged for a locksmith and a removal service to enter the flat forcibly and to start removing the applicant ’s belongings from it . The police arrived after a call from the applicant and the operation was halted .

The applicant filed a criminal complaint about the incident and joined a claim for damages to it . On her complaint , PERSON and PERSON were indicted to stand trial on a charge of having organised a breaking and entry within the meaning of LAW . They were first found guilty in summary proceedings , but the conviction was quashed on appeal . They were then acquitted in ordinary proceedings , but the acquittal was quashed on appeal . The proceedings are still pending .
On DATE the applicant lodged a separate action for damages resulting from the incident of DATE . It is still pending .

Mr B. again sought the applicant ’s eviction by way of a court action . It was stayed by ORG on DATE pending the outcome of the proceedings concerning the validity of the transfer of the flat to Mr. PERSON The action for eviction is still pending .

In DATE PERSON was registered in ORG as residing permanently in the flat . The registration was investigated following the applicant ’s criminal complaint , but no charges were ever brought . The matter was found to be entirely of a private - law nature and , as such , fell within the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts . No criminal case to answer was detected .

On DATE the applicant brought an action in GPE ORG seeking an injunction to restrain Mr B. from disturbing her peaceful enjoyment of the flat . At the same time she sought an interim injunction preventing him from entering the flat . On DATE the matter was transmitted to the Bratislava I ORG , which had the territorial jurisdiction to entertain it . It is still pending there .

On DATE the applicant brought an action against the cooperative in the Bratislava I ORG seeking a judicial ruling declaring the contract of sale of DATE void on grounds of illegality in that PERSON had previously been deprived of his membership of the cooperative and , as such , no longer qualified to have the flat transferred to him under LAW .
On DATE the Bratislava I ORG transmitted the action to GPE ORG , which had territorial jurisdiction .
On DATE the Bratislava III ORG invited the defendant to submit observations in reply and the applicant to pay the court fee , which she did on DATE .
On DATE and DATE ORG held hearings .
On DATE ORG held another hearing following which , on DATE , it dismissed the action as unfounded .

On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal . On ORG request , on DATE and CARDINAL DATE , respectively , the applicant corrected her appeal and paid the court fee . On DATE the applicant supplemented her appeal .

On DATE ORG held a hearing . It had to be adjourned as the applicant had challenged the president of ORG chamber on grounds of bias . On DATE the applicant supplemented the reasons for the challenge .
On DATE ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) dismissed the challenge as unfounded .

On DATE ORG quashed the judgment of DATE for procedural shortcomings and remitted the matter to ORG for reexamination . The court observed inter alia that the action should have been directed against both parties to the contract .

On DATE ORG invited the applicant ’s lawyer to correct the action by identifying the defendants in line with the judgment of DATE . On DATE the lawyer informed ORG that on DATE the applicant had withdrawn his power of attorney .
On DATE ORG forwarded the invitation to correct the action directly to the applicant , who responded on DATE .
On DATE , on the applicant ’s motion , the ORG admitted PERSON to the proceedings as the second defendant in the action .

In their submissions to ORG filed in DATE , respectively , the cooperative and its former in - house lawyer conceded that the re - admission of PERSON as a member in DATE had been contrary to law and to the statute of the cooperative . They also admitted that there had been shortcomings in the transfer of the flat to him and expressed doubts as to the accuracy of the internal records concerning his re - admission .

DATE and DATE ORG held CARDINAL hearings . The hearing called for DATE was adjourned due to the absence of the applicant , her lawyer and a witness . It was also noted that , DATE previously , the applicant had challenged the ORG judge dealing with the case for bias . The applicant completed the challenge by submitting new information and documents on DATE and DATE .
On DATE ORG dismissed the challenge as unsubstantiated .
A hearing held before FAC on DATE was adjourned until DATE and again until DATE .

On DATE ORG held a hearing following which , on DATE , it dismissed the action . It concluded that the applicant did not have a “ pressing legal interest ” in obtaining the ruling sought , which was a conditio sine qua non under LAW ) of LAW for the ruling to be made . Her legal status as regards the flat was defined by the judgment of DATE under which she had an absolute right to stay in the flat until alternative accommodation had been provided to her . The contract of DATE did not concern her directly and its validity had no effect on her own legal position . The applicant appealed against this judgment .
On DATE , following a hearing of the appeal on DATE , ORG upheld the judgment of DATE , concurring fully with ORG findings and conclusions . The judgment became final and binding on DATE .

In DATE the applicant requested that the Prosecutor General exercise his discretionary power and lodge an extraordinary appeal on points of law ( mimoriadne dovolanie ) on her behalf against the judgments of DATE and DATE . She argued that those judgments were legally wrong and violated her right to respect for her private life and home .

On DATE the Prosecutor General acceded to the applicant ’s request and lodged the appeal . He maintained that the applicant did have a “ pressing legal interest ” in having the action determined as she had been living in the flat for DATE , she was a member of the cooperative and had sought to obtain the flat under LAW , and that PERSON had been taking various illegal and unacceptable measures to have her evicted from it . In contrast , PERSON had vacated the flat DATE , his rights under the judgment of DATE were statuebarred , he had been excluded from the cooperative , his readmission to it was flawed and he was not eligible to have the flat transferred to him under LAW . ORG maintained that the contract of sale of DATE was illegal and should be declared void .

On DATE ORG dismissed the extraordinary appeal . The applicant had the right to stay in the flat until she had been provided with an alternative dwelling under the DATE judgment . If she was being disturbed in exercising this right , she could seek judicial protection against the trespasser . Her right to stay could not be interpreted as entailing her standing to sue . The transfer of ownership of the flat from the cooperative to PERSON had no effect on her legal position . The applicant must have known that PERSON had a recognised legal title to the flat and thus could not claim to have acted bona fide in obtaining the title herself . The applicant therefore lacked a “ pressing legal interest ” in the action and , consequently , could not challenge the contract of DATE .

On DATE the applicant , who was represented by a lawyer , lodged a complaint under LAW which she completed on DATE . She maintained that the length of the proceedings in her action of DATE , as conducted before ORG and ORG , had been excessive and that their respective decisions of DATE and DATE had been arbitrary and legally wrong and had violated her right to respect for her private life and home .

On DATE ORG ( Ústavný súd ) declared the complaint inadmissible . As to the length of the proceedings in their phase before ORG , they had ended by the judgment of DATE . Their examination thus could not bring about their acceleration . In line with ORG established practice , such an examination was not therefore required . ORG did not address the length of the proceedings before ORG .

The examination of the subjectmatter of the applicant ’s action was primarily the task of the ordinary courts . They had proceeded in accordance with the applicable procedural rules and had given adequate reasons for their decisions . ORG discerned no element of arbitrariness in the contested judgments and found that the remainder of the application was therefore manifestly ill - founded .

In DATE the applicant turned to ORG again . She sought to challenge the judgments of ORG , ORG and ORG of , respectively , DATE , DATE and DATE on the ground that they had violated her right to respect for her private and family life and her home .
On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible as out of time in that it had been lodged outside the statutory twomonth timelimit .
